abstract.p: Dr Paul R Epstein letter on Jan 22, 23 and 25 articles on crises linked to heavy dependence on fossil fuels calls for energy conservation policies that use clean energy sources

block.p: An oil spill in the Galápagos; an energy crisis in California; and global warming accelerating (news articles, Jan. 22, 23 and 25). Common to all is our dependence on fossil fuels: their extraction, mining, refining, transport and combustion.

An oil spill in the Galápagos; an energy crisis in California; and global warming accelerating (news articles, Jan. 22, 23 and 25). Common to all is our dependence on fossil fuels: their extraction, mining, refining, transport and combustion.

From fragile ecosystems to choking cities, oil and coal play profoundly destructive roles. Today, the ocean is warming, ice is melting and water vapor is rising. How many disasters will it take before we adopt energy conservation policies that use clean energy sources? The proper incentives could make the energy conversion a boon to the global economy.
PAUL R. EPSTEIN, M.D. Boston, Jan. 25, 2001
The writer is associate director, Center for Health and the Global Environment, Harvard Medical School.
